A cluster of indicator lamps and a numeric display sits on a pedestal, like it expects a person to stand here and feel responsible.
Labels are hand-applied: some typed, some stamped, some written in pencil and then “made official” with clear tape.
The readouts don’t say ON or OFF. They say:
ROTATION: CONTINUOUS
ALIGNMENT: UNCONFIRMED / LAST: [blank]
LOAD: STABLE (PER AGREEMENT)

There’s no answer—only the quiet insistence of the display.
A tiny sticker beneath it says: IF QUESTIONED, REFER TO APPENDIX D.
Appendix D is not present.

Appendix D is the kind of addendum that exists to make responsibility transferrable.
It usually defines witness thresholds, recording requirements, and what counts as “presence” when someone later asks why a procedure happened without a second set of eyes.
Here, it’s referenced like a shield and missing like a confession.

You can’t reconstruct it from the labels alone.
The reference is doing its job: it points somewhere that can’t contradict the panel today, but can contradict you later.
